Hereby the paper specifically focuses on changes in intra-household resource allocations (as a result of the introduction of palm oil agriculture) and the effect thereof on the role (and consequently well-being) of women in the area.

Annelies Zoomers (Utrecht University). 

For this project I conducted 3,5 months of fieldwork research in Farfar, Ghana, working with the Adaptation Learning Program (ALP), an adaptation intervention implemented by CARE International. Using a landscape approach, the research explores dynamics of changing land tenure regimes, generated as a result of planned adaptation interventions, and the effects these changes have on the relationships between sedentary dry-season watermelon-farmers and Fulani pastoralist communities. In order to make future adaptation policies and plans more conflict sensitive. 

The project is funded within the program of Conflict and Cooperation in the Management of Climate Change (CCMCC), which is funded by the UK's Department for International Development (DFID) through the Dutch Council for Scientific Research (NWO). More information: http://www.adaptationlandscapes.org', 'title': 'Researcher', 'employment_type': None}]}]
